thread.section_title: Business News, Economy, Finance & ASX Market News
thread.title: Ski Club of Victoria to develop Mt Buller land
thread.title_full: Ski Club of Victoria to develop Mt Buller land

author: Marc Pallisco
title: Ski Club of Victoria to develop Mt Buller land
text:
An artist's impression of the proposed Ski Club Victoria project, The Whitt Apartments in Mt Buller.
The Ski Club of Victoria is the latest organisation to turn property developer unveiling plans to build a four-level apartment block on its Mt Buller holding by the 2016 ski season.
Funds raised from the $3.5 million-plus project, The Whitt Apartments, will be invested to improve SCV's other Mt Buller accommodation facilities as well as amenities for members and guests.
Melbourne architect Peter McIntyre, also a SCV member, has designed the 12-unit project at no charge.
Adjacent to SCV's The Whitt, and next door to the Woolybutt, The Whitt Apartments are priced from $590,000 and include a car park, laundry, drying and storing facilities. They are being marketed with a flexible floorplan able to accommodate between two and four bedrooms.
Advertisement A short distance to Bourke Street and Athletes Walk, occupants within The Whitt Apartments will also enjoy north facing views.
Mark Adams Real Estate is selling apartments for the SCV. The proposed flats were exclusively offered to SCV members prior to the public campaign.
SCV says the development will not proceed unless all apartments are sold. If they exchange however, building could start as early as next month.
Like the beach house market, Victoria's alpine sector is more susceptible to market rises and falls than the metropolitan property sectors, but can offer investors, at times, a strong rental return, if at times, no capital gain.
In 2011, developer and publisher Morry Schwartz, with business partner, Callum Fraser, made a high-profile exit from the Falls Creek market, using a "no reserve" auction to offload 74 properties, which ended up selling for a fraction of their retail cost.
However the sector is showing signs of strength this season. In June, Autobahn founder Garry Dumbrell paid developer Rino Grollo $1.7 million for the luxury Howqua penthouse within the Mount Buller Chalet.
Also in that facility, which is near to SCV's The Whitt Apartments, businesswoman Rose Yong, responsible for bringing thousands of wealthy Asian investors to the state each year, purchased a strata retail space for use as a high end eatery, described as "The Flower Drum of the high country".
